ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the different types of study designs, how to critically assess the methods chosen in a study and how to calculate different measures of disease occurrence.

This course provided me with a robust understanding of chronic diseases, enabling me to analyze their distribution, determinants, and risk factors at both the population and individual levels.

By engaging with real-world data sets, I've developed valuable analytical skills using statistical tools, enhancing my ability to interpret and evaluate epidemiological studies in the context of chronic disease.

The course's focus on preventative strategies has given me insights into designing and implementing public health interventions, leading to a more profound appreciation for the complexities involved in chronic disease control.

Through collaborative projects, I've cultivated teamwork and communication skills, learning to effectively articulate and share ideas with a diverse group of peers.

By critically assessing contemporary research, I've gained the ability to discern the strengths and weaknesses in study designs, fostering a more nuanced approach to scientific inquiry in the field of epidemiology.

I've gained exposure to ethical considerations and cultural contexts in chronic disease epidemiology, shaping my perspective on the multifaceted role that socio-economic factors play in health outcomes.
Various terminologies in epi, learning how to critique a paper and evaluation methodology
Great introduction to epidemiology, understanding measures of disease frequency, measures of disease comparison, study designs, confounding and effect modification, bias and screening
I learned the basics of study design, measures of disease frequency, and methods of assessing the validity of studies.

Through this course, I was able to learn the foundations of epidemiology. This included foundational definitions, concepts, types of studies and how to apply it to real-life practice in public health.

I learned a lot of topics I had seen before but never truly had the background for. I feel like I now have the tools to effectively read an article and understand every aspect from it (tables, methods, etc.).
I learn to recognize the different types of study designs, calculate ORs, RRs, etc. How to recognize effect modification vs confounding, types of bias.
I learned how to critically assess a scientific article and understand the do's and don't-s of picking a study design.

Dr. Desai's was phenomenal and I walked away with the following:
1. ability to understand and interpret the common terms of measures of disease occurrence and epidemiology, which were previously confusing and misleading for me,
2. the clear understanding of the various types of study designs and the type of research question each study design hopes to answer. This was a major takeaway for me since research articles on each of the various types of study design were discussed and dissected in class till we were absolutely clear on the concepts,
3. the ability to decide on the most suitable type of study design given a particular research question. This again was an incredible outcome from the class,
4. the knowledge of measures of associations in epidemiology and the appropriate interpretation of them in studies.
KNowledge of epidemiology, various studies and how to conduct research and critically assess research methodologies

narratives.question_text: What actions did you take that helped your learning in this course?
comments: I watched the pre-recorded lectures before class and paid attention in class

Active Participation and Engagement: By consistently participating in class discussions, engaging with peers, and asking thoughtful questions, I was able to deepen my understanding of complex topics. This proactive approach allowed me to clarify any uncertainties and apply the theoretical knowledge in practical scenarios, enriching my overall learning experience.

Dedicated Self-Study and Utilization of Resources: Recognizing the importance of individual effort, I devoted time outside of class to review lecture materials, read supplementary texts, and practice using statistical tools. By leveraging the resources provided by Instructor Desai and exploring additional reference materials, I was able to reinforce my understanding of the subject matter, ensuring a well-rounded and comprehensive grasp of chronic disease epidemiology.
Homework and discussions, the videos helped me go back revise and review certain topics

reading lecture notes ahead of class
watching videos posted ahead of class
completing assignments
Consistently watching the recorded lectures and reviewing the slides after the in-person lectures helped the material hit home.
I set up office hours to ask about a homework assignment and overall material. I was also able to work in groups to discuss the material.
I watched the videos and took notes on the slides provided. This was very useful for doing the homework.
Homeworks, reading the papers, participating in class
Reading the articles, especially the discussion articles and re-reading the lecture slides.

The actions that helped the learning in this course were:

1. reading the class lecture handouts before class,
2. reading the papers for discussion before class,
3. active participation in class,
4. watching pre-recorded videos for class,
5. completing the assignments
Reading text books, reading review articles online and those recommended by instructor.
